title: Section 1 Unit 1

examples.japanese: すし、ください。
examples.english: Sushi, please.

examples.japanese: おちゃ、ください！
examples.english: Green tea, please!

examples.japanese: ごはんとみず、ください！
examples.english: Rice and water, please!

examples.japanese: みずです。
examples.english: It's water.

tips: Welcome to Japanese! | Japanese has three writing systems. In hiragana, which you can use to write most Japanese words, each character represents a syllable, and there are no spaces between words. We use romaji to represent Japanese sounds using the Roman alphabet: | すしとみず [sushi to mizu] sushi and water | In Japanese, verbs go at the end: | すしです。 [sushi desu] It's sushi.

title: Section 1 Unit 2

examples.japanese: いしゃです。
examples.english: She's a doctor.

examples.japanese: せんせいです。
examples.english: He's a teacher.

examples.japanese: かっこいいべんごしです。
examples.english: She's a cool lawyer.

examples.japanese: やさしいひとです！
examples.english: He's a nice person!

tips: A teacher, the teacher | Japanese does not have words like a or the. For example, the word せんせい [sensei] can mean both teacher and a teacher.

title: Section 1 Unit 3

examples.japanese: こんにちは、はなです。
examples.english: Hello, I'm Hana.

examples.japanese: こんばんは。
examples.english: Good evening.

examples.japanese: じゃあね、またあした。
examples.english: Bye, see you tomorrow.

tips: R‑E‑S‑P‑E‑C‑T | When you address someone, you use the title さん [san] after their name to show respect. When you use this with somebody's first name, it doesn't have a translation in English. | けんさん、こんにちは。 [Ken‑san, konnichiwa] Hello, Ken. | Notice that greetings like hello and bye often come before the name in English, but after it in Japanese.

title: Section 1 Unit 4

examples.japanese: これはカレーです。
examples.english: This is curry.

examples.japanese: それはラーメンです。
examples.english: That's ramen.

examples.japanese: それはおいしいですか。
examples.english: Is that tasty?

tips: On topic | Using は [wa] after a word makes it the topic of the sentence. The rest of the sentence is a comment about it. | カレーはおいしいです。 [karee wa oishii desu] Curry is tasty. | The hiragana は is only pronounced wa as a topic marker. Otherwise, it is pronounced ha.

title: Section 1 Unit 5

examples.japanese: アメリカはおおきいです。
examples.english: America is big.

examples.japanese: カナダじんです。
examples.english: I'm Canadian.

examples.japanese: けんさんはブラジルじんですか。
examples.english: Is Ken Brazilian?

examples.japanese: なおみさんはイギリスじんです。
examples.english: Naomi is British.

tips: I'm Japanese! | You’ve seen that hiragana and katakana can be mixed in the same sentence. They can also be mixed within a single word! Compare the examples below: | これはアメリカです。 [kore wa Amerika desu] This is America. | わたしはアメリカじんです。 [watashi wa Amerikajin desu] I'm American.

title: Section 1 Unit 6

examples.japanese: ホテルはどこですか。
examples.english: Where is the hotel?

examples.japanese: バスていはここですか。
examples.english: Is the bus stop here?

examples.japanese: これはデパートですか。
examples.english: Is this a department store?

examples.japanese: なおみさんはどこですか。
examples.english: Where is Naomi?

tips: Where are we? | In Japanese, most question words come right before ですか [desu ka]. Compare the following questions: | ホテルはここですか。 [hoteru wa koko desu ka] Is the hotel here? | ホテルはどこですか。 [hoteru wa doko desu ka] Where's the hotel? | Remember that words like hotel in Japanese can be translated as hotel, a hotel, or the hotel depending on the context!

title: Section 1 Unit 7

examples.japanese: これはわたしのぼうしです。
examples.english: This is my hat.

examples.japanese: わたしのかさはあかいです。
examples.english: My umbrella is red.

examples.japanese: わたしのくつはどこですか。
examples.english: Where is my shoe?

examples.japanese: これらはわたしのコートです。
examples.english: These are my coats.

tips: My word! | To say something belongs to you, use the phrase わたしの [watashi no]: | これはわたしのかさです。 [kore wa watashi no kasa desu] This is my umbrella.

title: Section 1 Unit 8

examples.japanese: たなかさんはあかるいひとです。
examples.english: Mr. Tanaka is a cheerful person.

examples.japanese: なかやまさんはかっこいいです。
examples.english: Ms. Nakayama is cool.

examples.japanese: やまぐちなおみさんはおもしろいです。
examples.english: Naomi Yamaguchi is funny.

examples.japanese: なかやまはなさんはやさしいですか。
examples.english: Is Hana Nakayama nice?

tips: Won't you be my neighbor? | You’ve seen さん [san] used after a first name to show respect when addressing or describing someone else. It can also be used after a last name and translated as Mr. or Ms. | たなかさんはやさしいです。 [Tanaka‑san wa yasashii desu] Mr./Ms. Tanaka is nice. | When using both first and last names in Japanese, the last name comes first. | なかやまはなさんです。 [Nakayama Hana‑san desu] She's Hana Nakayama.

title: Section 1 Unit 9

examples.japanese: 一じです。
examples.english: It's one o'clock.

examples.japanese: いま二じです。
examples.english: It's two o'clock now.

examples.japanese: すみません、いまなんじですか。
examples.english: Excuse me, what time is it now?

tips: Time to learn kanji! | The kanji writing system is used for most words in Japanese. There are over 2,000 kanji characters.  Kanji can really help you tell words apart! For example, notice the words that sound the same in the following sentences: | たなかさん、こんにちは。 [Tanaka‑san, konnichiwa] Hello, Mr. Tanaka. | さんじです。 [sanji desu] It's three o'clock. | Some kanji look like what they mean. See how the kanji for one, two, and three have that many lines: | In this course, you’ll slowly learn more and more about kanji.

title: Section 1 Unit 10

examples.japanese: すみません、ちかてつはどこですか。
examples.english: Excuse me, where's the subway?

examples.japanese: これはわたしのパスポートじゃないです。
examples.english: This isn't my passport.

examples.japanese: それは中山さんのスマホです。
examples.english: That is Ms. Nakayama's smartphone.

tips: That's (not) the ticket! | To make a statement with です [desu] negative, use じゃないです [janai desu]. | それはわたしのきっぷじゃないです。 [sore wa watashi no kippu janai desu] That's not my ticket.

title: Section 2 Unit 1

examples.japanese: 田中さん、おはようございます！
examples.english: Good morning, Mr. Tanaka!

examples.japanese: しゅっしんはどこですか。
examples.english: Where are you from?

examples.japanese: 京都はにぎやかですか。
examples.english: Is Kyoto lively?

tips: Asking Questions | Asking questions in Japanese is easy! Just add か (ka) to the end of a normal sentence, after the verb! | If you want to ask something like What is your name? in Japanese, it’s more like Your name is what? And don’t forget to use か (ka)!

title: Section 2 Unit 2

examples.japanese: 父はやさしいです。
examples.english: My dad is nice.

examples.japanese: おとうとはうるさいです。
examples.english: My younger brother is noisy.

examples.japanese: むすこはゆうめいです！
examples.english: My son is famous!

examples.japanese: つまはあかるいひとです。
examples.english: My wife is a cheerful person.

tips: Easy as 1, 2, 3 | In this skill, you'll learn to say some numbers in Japanese!

title: Section 2 Unit 3

examples.japanese: アニメを見ます。
examples.english: I watch anime.

examples.japanese: サッカーをしますか。
examples.english: Do you play soccer?

examples.japanese: はなさんはよく本を読みます。
examples.english: Hana often reads books.

examples.japanese: Jポップをききますか。
examples.english: Do you listen to J-pop?

tips: What are you eating? | When you do something to a noun, like when you eat something or drink something, put を (o) after the thing that receives the action. | Also, you may notice that verbs in Japanese often end with ‑ます (‑masu). Notice that ‑ます (‑masu) verbs can refer to either the present or the future, depending on context. It’s like when we say I’m eating now or I’m eating dinner later in English! | You can also use を (o) when asking for something! Just put it after the thing you want, then add please! | You might see that the pronunciation of を is often written as wo. But when it’s used in a sentence this way, the sound is closer to just o!

title: Section 2 Unit 4

examples.japanese: すしをたべますか。
examples.english: Do you eat sushi?

examples.japanese: まいあさコーヒーをのみます。
examples.english: I drink coffee every morning.

examples.japanese: 九時にばんごはんをたべますか。
examples.english: Do you eat dinner at nine o'clock?

tips: What time is it? | To ask What time is it? in Japanese, say 何時ですか (nanji desu ka) To give an answer, just say the number and add 時 (ji)! | 二時です。 Ni‑ji desu. (It) is two o’clock. | 時 (ji) literally means hour, so you’re really asking What hour is it? | Combining Numbers | In Japanese, you just combine the numbers above to make bigger numbers. Take a look! | If you want to say 18, it’s ten plus eight. | 40 is four tens! | So for 48, it’s four tens, plus eight!

title: Section 2 Unit 5

examples.japanese: 新しいスカートがほしいです。
examples.english: I want a new skirt.

examples.japanese: このぼうしはちょっと…
examples.english: I don't really like this hat...

examples.japanese: あのジャケットはかっこいいですね。
examples.english: That jacket over there is cool, isn't it?

examples.japanese: すみません、これはいくらですか。
examples.english: Excuse me, how much is this?

tips: I want it that way! | To say what you want in Japanese, you can use the phrase 欲しいです. Be sure to put a が after the thing that you want! | Put a は after something you don’t want!

examples.japanese: うどんていしょくはいくらですか。
examples.english: How much is the udon meal set?

examples.japanese: ラーメンをひとつください。
examples.english: One ramen, please.

examples.japanese: コーヒーをふたつください。
examples.english: Two coffees, please.

examples.japanese: はなさん、みそしるはどうですか。
examples.english: Hana, how is the miso soup?

examples.japanese: そのそばはおいしいですか。
examples.english: Is that soba tasty?

title: Section 2 Unit 7

examples.japanese: まいにちおよぎます。
examples.english: I swim every day.

examples.japanese: ヨガをしますか。
examples.english: Do you do yoga?

examples.japanese: 土曜日はひとりでまんがを読みます。
examples.english: On Saturdays, I read manga by myself.

examples.japanese: よくともだちとゲームをします。
examples.english: I often play video games with friends.

tips: Work Hard, Play Hard | In English we sometimes say things like do work, do yoga, and so on. Similarly, many Japanese verbs are made by adding します (shimasu) to nouns. | Note that with these noun and verb combinations, を(o) is optional!

title: Section 2 Unit 8

examples.japanese: すみません、かいさつはどこですか。
examples.english: Excuse me, where is the ticket gate?

examples.japanese: ATMはにかいです。
examples.english: The ATM is on the second floor.

examples.japanese: エレベーターはありますか。
examples.english: Do you have an elevator?

tips: は vs が? | We’ve seen a handful of hiragana characters like へ (e) and に (ni) (examples), which you place after a word to show what role it has in the sentence. Let’s look at two that are quite similar: | In short, は (wa) goes with a topic that’s been already mentioned or is implied, and が (ga) is used to give more attention to the subject in question. | 田中さんは学生ですか？ Tanaka‑san wa gakusei desu ka? Is Tanaka a student? | 田中さんは学生です。 Tanaka‑san wa gakusei desu. Tanaka is a student. | In the above conversation, everyone knows who Tanaka is. The important information is that he’s a student! | 田中さんが学生です。 Tanaka‑san ga gakusei desu. Tanaka is a student. | This sentence could be the answer to Who is a student? Here, Tanaka is the new and important information. | In the same line of thought, many questions and negative sentences often use は (wa). This is used when the thing you’re talking about is background information, and other parts of the sentence are more important. | 水はのみますか？ Mizu wa nomimasu ka? Do (you) drink water? | 水はのみません。 Mizu wa nomimasen. (I) do not drink water. | It’s not incorrect to use は (wa) instead of が (ga)  (or vice versa!), it just changes the focus of the sentence a bit. | These are some basic pointers, but don’t stress about it! There are many other rules and situations that can’t always be translated easily. Just focus on learning the sentence patterns as a whole. As you learn more, you can continue getting a feel for the more subtle nuances of Japanese.

title: Section 2 Unit 9

examples.japanese: 何時におきますか。
examples.english: What time do you get up?

examples.japanese: ときどき四時ごろドラマを見ます。
examples.english: I sometimes watch dramas around four o'clock.

examples.japanese: らいしゅうあにとコーヒーを飲みます。
examples.english: I'm going to drink coffee with my older brother next week.

examples.japanese: らいしゅうでかけますか。
examples.english: Are you going to go out next week?

tips: I always use Duolingo! | You use words like いつも and よく to indicate how often you do something in Japanese.

title: Section 2 Unit 10

examples.japanese: こんにちは、アンドリューと言います。
examples.english: Hello, my name is Andrew.

examples.japanese: こちらは私のかのじょです。
examples.english: This is my girlfriend.

examples.japanese: はなさん、しゅみはありますか。
examples.english: Hana, do you have any hobbies?

tips: What do you like? | We’ve seen です (desu) can mean to be, as in 学生です (gakusei desu). But です (desu) is used in many other situations that aren’t translatable to English. | For example, to say I like water! or I like tea!, use が  (ga) to mark the thing you like, then end with 好きです (suki desu). | 水が好きです。 Mizu ga suki desu. (I) like water. | お茶が好きです。 Ocha ga suki desu. (I) like tea. | Don’t like it? Change 好きです (suki desu) to 好きじゃないです (suki janai desu)! | 野菜は好きじゃないです。 Yasai wa suki janai desu. (I) do not like vegetables. | Want to work on your pronunciation? In some Japanese words, the vowels are almost not pronounced at all. Take a listen!

title: Section 2 Unit 11

examples.japanese: らいしゅうひっこします。
examples.english: I'm going to move next week.

examples.japanese: 新しいアパートはどうですか。
examples.english: How's the new apartment?

examples.japanese: エアコンはありません。
examples.english: I don't have an air conditioner.

examples.japanese: まだ古いせんたくきがあります。
examples.english: I still have an old washing machine.

examples.japanese: こんしゅう大きいほんだなを買います。
examples.english: I'm going to buy a big bookshelf this week.

tips: There’s a dog! | In English, we’d say There is a table or There are tables. In Japanese, you can use the verb あります (arimasu)! Keep in mind, nouns in Japanese have the same form, whether you’re talking about one thing or many things. In a conversation, you can tell based on context, or it’s just not important. | But, if you want to say something like There is a cat, you actually need to use います (imasu) instead of あります (arimasu)! あります (arimasu) is for inanimate things, while います (imasu) is for people and animals!

examples.japanese: すみません、このでんしゃはしぶやえきに行きますか。
examples.english: Excuse me, does this train go to Shibuya Station?

examples.japanese: つぎのえきはよこはまえきですか。
examples.english: Is the next station Yokohama Station?

examples.japanese: どのぐらいかかりますか。
examples.english: About how long does it take?

title: Section 2 Unit 13

examples.japanese: 京都えきはほんとうにきれいなえきですね。
examples.english: Kyoto Station is a really pretty train station, isn't it?

examples.japanese: あのたてものは何ですか。
examples.english: What is that building over there?

examples.japanese: これはゆうめいなじんじゃですか。
examples.english: Is this a famous shrine?

examples.japanese: そのすてきなポストカードはいくらですか。
examples.english: How much is that lovely postcard?

tips: それ vs. あれ | それ (sore) and あれ (are) both mean that, so what’s the difference? | それ (sore) is to talk about things near the listener. (As opposed to これ (kore), which refers to things near the speaker.) | それは何ですか？ Sore wa nan desu ka? What is that? | あれ (are) refers to something that isn’t near the speaker or the listener! | あれは何ですか？ Are wa nan desu ka? What is that (over there)?

title: Section 2 Unit 14

examples.japanese: すみません、だいじょうぶですか。
examples.english: Excuse me, are you alright?

examples.japanese: きゅうきゅうしゃをおねがいします。
examples.english: I need an ambulance, please.

examples.japanese: 私のでんわばんごうは〇八の三四五六です。
examples.english: My phone number is 08-3456.

examples.japanese: アレルギーはありますか。
examples.english: Do you have any allergies?

tips: Introduce yourself! | Where do you live? In English, we’d say I live in.... In Japanese, you end your sentence with the phrase ...住んでいます (sunde imasu)! Remember to use に (ni) after the location. | As for age, we’d say something like I am ten years old in English. In Japanese, you’d use 歳 (sai). | In Japan, this is especially useful information. You often address people older than you with more politeness, even if they’re just a couple years older! | There are pronunciation changes with a couple of the smaller numbers. Take a look!

title: Section 2 Unit 15

examples.japanese: てんきはどうですか。
examples.english: How's the weather?

examples.japanese: はれの日はうみに行きます。
examples.english: On sunny days, I go to the beach.

examples.japanese: きょうのてんきはいいです。
examples.english: Today's weather will be nice.

examples.japanese: ゆきの日はあたたかいおちゃを飲みます。
examples.english: On snowy days, I drink warm green tea.

tips: Every! Single! Time! | The kanji 毎 can attach to lots of words to mean every.

title: Section 2 Unit 16

examples.japanese: きょうだいはいますか。
examples.english: Do you have siblings?

examples.japanese: いもうとはちゅうごくごができます。
examples.english: My younger sister knows Chinese.

examples.japanese: あねはオーストラリアにすんでいます。
examples.english: My older sister lives in Australia.

examples.japanese: おこさんは日本ごができますか。
examples.english: Do your kids know Japanese?

tips: How’s the family? | Japanese has lots of words to talk about family! When you talk to your family members, or when you talk about other people’s family, you generally use the words that end with that respectful ‑さん (san). | おかえりなさい、お父さん。 Okaerinasai, otо̄san. Welcome back, Dad. | お母さんはお元気ですか？ Okāsan wa o‑genki desu ka? Is (your) mother well? | 彼のお姉さんは大学生です。 Kare no onēsan wa daigakusei desu. His older sister is a college student. | But, when you talk to others about your own family, you actually use different words! | Notice that if you have two nouns, you can put も  (mo) after each one to mean both my father and my mother!

title: Section 2 Unit 17

examples.japanese: まいにちしごとに行きます。
examples.english: I go to work every day.

examples.japanese: いつもちゃんとしゅくだいをします。
examples.english: I always make sure to do homework.

examples.japanese: 休みの日は何をしますか。
examples.english: On days off, what do you do?

tips: Counting People | Remember, when you count nouns, you need to use a counter with the number. We’ve seen 人 in words like 日本人 (nihonjin). This kanji means person, and you also use it to count people. | 兄が一人います。 Ani ga hitori imasu. (I) have one older brother. | 姉が二人います。 Ane ga futari imasu. (I) have two older sisters. | 一人 (hitori) and 二人 (futari) have irregular pronunciation. But from 三 (san) and up, you can pretty much just add 人! Notice that with numbers, it’s pronounced nin. | 彼はお兄さんが三人います。 Kare wa onīsan ga san‑nin imasu. He has three older brothers. | 彼女はお姉さんが四人います。 Kanojo wa onēsan ga yo‑nin imasu. She has four older sisters.

title: Section 2 Unit 18
meaning: Say what you want to do

examples.japanese: 来月何をしましょうか。
examples.english: What should we do next month?

examples.japanese: このひこうきのチケットはほんとうに高いですね。
examples.english: This plane ticket is really expensive, isn't it?

examples.japanese: カフェでコーヒーを飲みましょう。
examples.english: We should drink coffee at the cafe.

examples.japanese: あさごはんのあと、どうぶつえんに行きましょう。
examples.english: After breakfast, we should go to the zoo.

title: Section 2 Unit 19

examples.japanese: ごりょうしんはらいしゅう日本に来ますか。
examples.english: Are your parents coming to Japan next week?

examples.japanese: 金曜日に何をしますか。
examples.english: What are you going to do on Friday?

examples.japanese: しんかんせんは何時ですか。
examples.english: What time is the bullet train?

examples.japanese: つぎのりょこうがたのしみです。
examples.english: I'm looking forward to the next trip.

tips: Days of Our Lives | In English, we say on Monday. In Japanese, you put に after days of the week to show when you do something. | You can use also は after the day. This shows that you’re talking more about that day itself, as opposed to what you’re doing on that day. | But words like あした or 今日 can’t be followed by に (ni)! Instead, use は (wa)! | Notice that in addition to と (to) meaning and, you can also use と (to) to say who you do something with!

title: Section 2 Unit 20

examples.japanese: ケーキはすきですか。
examples.english: Do you like cake?

examples.japanese: おかしやで何を買いましょうか。
examples.english: What should we buy at the pastry shop?

examples.japanese: ドーナツを四つください！
examples.english: Four donuts, please!

examples.japanese: あのチョコレートのパイは五百えんです。
examples.english: That chocolate pie over there is five hundred yen.

tips: Which This is This? | Use words like この (kono) before a noun, like This food is great! Use words like これ (kore) when you don’t mention the noun, like This is great! | この朝ご飯はおいしいです。 Kono asagohan wa oishī desu.  This breakfast is delicious. | これはいくらですか？ Kore wa ikura desu ka? How much is this? | Have you noticed? There’s a pattern in words that talk about things in the speaker’s space or things in the listener’s space. Take a look!

examples.japanese: いっしょにばんごはんをつくりましょう！
examples.english: We should make dinner together!

examples.japanese: しょうゆはありますか。
examples.english: Do you have any soy sauce?

examples.japanese: もっとやさいを買いましょう！
examples.english: We should buy more vegetables!

examples.japanese: 魚は食べますか。
examples.english: Do you eat fish?

examples.japanese: 中山せんせいのじゅぎょうはいつもたのしいです。
examples.english: Professor Nakayama's classes are always fun.

examples.japanese: 日本ごのせんせいはだれですか。
examples.english: Who is the Japanese teacher?

examples.japanese: きょうはじゅぎょうが四つあります。
examples.english: Today, I have four classes.

examples.japanese: なおみさん、じゅぎょうは何時におわりますか。
examples.english: What time does class end, Naomi?

examples.japanese: よくうちでしごとします。
examples.english: I often work at home.

examples.japanese: しゃしんかのしごとはたのしいです。
examples.english: Work as a photographer is fun.

examples.japanese: まいあさごぜん五時にしごとに行きます。

title: Section 2 Unit 24

tips: Colors | When saying what color something is in Japanese, we need to remember a few things! If the words end in 色 (which actually means color!), like オレンジ色, put a の between the color and the thing! | If the color comes after the thing it describes, の isn’t necessary. | If the color word ends with an い, you don’t need the の!

tips: あまり | When you use the word あまり with ‑ません, it shows that you don’t do something very much. | 彼女はあまり走りません。 She does not run very much. | 音楽はあまり聞きません。 (I) do not listen to music very much.

tips: When and where? | If you want to say when something happens, put に (ni) after the time! | You can also put に (ni) after a location to show where you’re going! | Similarly, you can also use へ (e) after a location to show where you’re going! Notice that in this situation, it’s pronounced e, not he! | What’s the difference? Well, に (ni) focuses on the journey and the destination of going somewhere, but へ (e) focuses more on the process of going. But don’t stress too much here. In daily life, they’re basically interchangeable.

title: Section 3 Unit 44

examples.japanese: 電気をつけてください。

tips: て Form | In Japanese, there’s a verb form that ends with て or で. You use the て form with ください to give requests! | If a verb has an e sound before ‑ます, remove ‑ます and add ‑て. | If a verb ends in ‑みます or ‑びます, remove the ending and add ‑んで. | There are a few other patterns and exceptions, as well. For example, します becomes して.

tips: Wearing me out | There are multiple words for to wear in Japanese. You can choose which word to use, based on where the clothing is on your body. | For hats, use かぶります. | For clothes on your upper body, use きます. | And use 履きます for clothes on your lower body!

tips: It’s a date! | If you want to ask someone out to dinner in Japanese, you need to know how to say the date!  For months, say the number of the month (for example, October is the 10th month) followed by 月. Then for the day, say the number followed by 日! | But you have to work a little harder if you want to go out on the 1st through the 10th, or even the 20th! Those days have their own unique pronunciation.

You use the て form with ください to give requests! | If a verb has an e sound before ‑ます, remove ‑ます and add ‑て. | If a verb ends in ‑みます or ‑びます, remove the ending and add ‑んで. | There are a few other patterns and exceptions, as well. For example, します becomes して.

tips: て Form | The て form of a verb is very useful! For example, we use て form with ください to nicely ask someone to do something, like in the sentence 座ってください. | For verbs that end with ‑します, you make the て form by replacing the ‑します  with ‑して. | For verbs that end with ‑います or ‑ります, remove that ending and add ‑って! | For a verb that ends with ‑きます, replace that ending with ‑いて.

tips: Plain Form | There is another verb form in Japanese called plain form. Plain form is what you see in dictionaries, and it’s often used when talking casually with friends. Here are some common examples! | You don’t need to worry too much about plain form at the moment — this is just a small introduction. But if you hear someone using these verbs with you, you’ll know they like you enough to be super casual with you!

examples.japanese: ノートを取るのは大切です。

title: Section 3 Unit 71

examples.english: Mastering foreign languages is not easy.

examples.japanese: 彼女は強いドイツ語なまりがある。
examples.english: She has a strong German accent.

examples.japanese: 彼はいくつかのノルウェー語の方言が話せる。
examples.english: He can speak a few Norwegian dialects.

examples.japanese: まあ、かわいそうに！
examples.english: Oh, what a pity!

examples.japanese: 何と面倒な！
examples.english: How troublesome!

examples.japanese: めちゃくちゃわくわくしている！
examples.english: I'm ridiculously excited!

examples.japanese: あいつには本当にいらいらする。
examples.english: I'm really irritated by that guy.

examples.japanese: 茂は地元の学校で理科を教えている。
examples.english: Shigeru is teaching science at a local school.

examples.japanese: 彼女の新しい理論は他の学者に重視された。
examples.english: Her new theory was emphasized by the other scholars.

examples.japanese: 顕微鏡で見ると細菌が見える。
examples.english: You can see the bacteria if you look through the microscope.

examples.japanese: 磁石は鉄を引き付ける。
examples.english: Magnets attract iron.

examples.japanese: 事業を始めました。
examples.english: I started a business.

examples.japanese: 私たちに資本を提供してくれる人を誰か見つけなさい。
examples.english: Find someone to provide capital for us.

examples.japanese: 我が社は資金不足のために計画を中止した。
examples.english: Our company cancelled the project due to a lack of funds.

examples.japanese: その事業は商業的に大失敗だった。
examples.english: The business was a massive failure commercially.

examples.japanese: 政府は意図的に情報を隠した。
examples.english: The government intentionally hid the information.

examples.japanese: 結論として三つのことを提案したいと思います。
examples.english: In conclusion, I would like to propose three things.

examples.japanese: 我々は現在彼女の提案を考慮中だ。
examples.english: We are currently considering her proposal.

examples.japanese: 結果は予想とはまったく異なっていた。
examples.english: The results were completely different from my expectations.

examples.japanese: 彼女のチームが勝つのはほぼ確実だ。
examples.english: It is almost certain that her team will win.

examples.japanese: 庭の雑草を取りました。
examples.english: I removed the weeds from the garden.

examples.japanese: 地震で崖が崩壊した。
examples.english: The cliff collapsed in the earthquake.

examples.japanese: これらの熱帯の花は庭でよく育つ。
examples.english: These tropical flowers grow well in the garden.

examples.japanese: 水が固まって氷になった。
examples.english: The water hardened and turned into ice.

examples.japanese: 市長は公衆の前で演説した。
examples.english: The mayor gave a speech in front of the general public.

examples.japanese: 彼女は強盗容疑で逮捕された。
examples.english: She was arrested on a robbery charge.

examples.japanese: 証人は見たままのことを述べた。
examples.english: The witness stated just what she had seen.

examples.japanese: 意地悪だね。
examples.english: You're mean, aren't you?

examples.japanese: 君はどっちの味方だ？
examples.english: Which side are you on?

examples.japanese: 彼は嘘をつく癖がある。
examples.english: He has a bad habit of telling lies.

examples.japanese: ああ、ほっとした！
examples.english: Oh, I'm relieved!

examples.japanese: 日本は四季がはっきりしている。
examples.english: The four seasons are distinct in Japan.

examples.japanese: 春は桜の季節です。
examples.english: Spring is the season for cherry blossoms.

examples.japanese: 梅雨が始まりました。
examples.english: The rainy season has begun.

examples.japanese: 九月の中ごろに月見をします。
examples.english: We go moon viewing around the middle of September.

examples.japanese: 元日に福袋を買うつもりです。
examples.english: I plan to buy a grab bag on New Year's Day.
